title: 110_hr2737
content: The "Health Care Relief Act of 2007" allows for a refundable credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Care Relief Act of 2007" provides a tax credit for previously uninsured individuals for health insurance coverage paid during the taxable year, with a limit of $1,000 ($2,000 for joint returns). Previously uninsured individuals are defined as those without health insurance in the 6-month period before obtaining coverage. The "Health Care Relief Act of 2007" offers a tax credit for previously uninsured individuals for health insurance coverage paid during the taxable year. The credit is limited to $1,000 ($2,000 for joint returns) and applies to those without health insurance in the 6-month period before obtaining coverage. Special rules include coordination with other benefits and denial of credit to dependents. The tax code is amended to include a new section and revise the table of sections for subpart C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code is amended to include a new section for small business health insurance expenses, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The tax code amendment introduces a health insurance credit for small employers, allowing a 35% credit on expenses for health insurance coverage under a new health plan. There are limitations on the expenses per employee, with a maximum of $800 for self-only coverage and $2,000 for family coverage. The tax code amendment introduces a health insurance credit for small employers, allowing a 35% credit on expenses for health insurance coverage under a new health plan. Expenses can only be taken into account if at least 65% of the coverage cost is borne by the employer for a 4-year period. Definitions for "health insurance coverage" and "new health plan" are provided. The term 'new health plan' refers to an employer arrangement providing health insurance coverage to employees, meeting specific criteria such as not being established in the previous two taxable years and covering at least 70% of qualified employees. The term 'qualified employee' includes any employee of an employer, including a leased employee. A 'small employer' is defined as an employer with 100 employees, with only qualified employees considered. Special rules apply, similar to section 52, and amounts from salary reduction arrangements are not counted under this section. The section provides for an inflation adjustment for dollar amounts in subsection (b) starting from 2008. Expenses incurred after January 1, 2014, are not covered under this section. The section amends the general business credit to include a health insurance credit for small employers. It also denies a double benefit by disallowing a deduction for expenses used to determine the health insurance credit. The general business credit is amended to include a health insurance credit for small employers. Controlled groups are treated as one person for this credit. The general business credit is amended to include a health insurance credit for small employers, with controlled groups treated as one person. The amendments made by this section apply to small business health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2007, for arrangements established after the enactment of this Act.
